abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Rural and Small Towns
            Water Supply and Sanitation Project (Praguas) in Ecuador
            were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: 1) The PRAGUAS project
            validates the viability of the demand-responsive approach to
            rural water supply to operate at scale at a national level
            and to deliver significant infrastructure outcomes over a
            five-year timeframe while involving rural beneficiaries in
            project selection, planning and operation; 2) The water
            supply and Sanitation (WSS) sector reform needs to move
            beyond line ministries and sector agencies to include the
            Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF), since sustainable
            sector reform requires the development of consistent
            financial incentives and coherent financial policies; 3) It
            is important to be realistic and acknowledge the fact that a
            community-driven project such as PRAGUAS requires more time
            to get acceptance from the community and start
            implementation; 4) In unstable country environments, a
            strong Project Management Unit (PMU) may be essential to
            project success; 5) The financial scheme of PRAGUAS was
            proven to be socially acceptable; 6) The on-site sanitation
            alternative of a basic sanitation unit comprising shower,
            sink and toilet (UBS) has proven to be an important success;
            7) The combination of technical assistance and clear,
            performance-based financial incentives for service
            delegation were effective in creating autonomous operators
            in a large number of municipalities; 8) Sustainability can
            be enhanced by pre-selecting municipalities that have: (i) a
            technical, social and financial team; (ii) municipal plans
            that include WSS and watershed protection plans; and (iii) a
            capable administrative/financial team; 9) Water Boards and
            communities should be assisted in the formulation of Social
            Plans that include community planning, tax payment,
            assessment of natural resources, and management of water
            sources; and 10) PRAGUAS' Operation Manual for
            financial and technical operations, administration, social
            control and auditing, should be disseminated more extensively.
